qas.question: What were the lawmakers beginning to drown in?
Whose cases did English courts cite early on?
When did decisions from English courts begin to be reported?
How many published volumes of American reports were there in 1879?
Where was the delegate who praised the American judicial literature from?
How many English law volumes were there in 1810?

context: Early on, <b10_0>American<b10_0/> courts, even after the Revolution, often did cite <a0_0>contemporary English<a0_0/> cases. This was because appellate decisions from many American courts were not regularly reported until the <a5_0><b11_0>mid-<a1_0>19th century<b11_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/>; lawyers and judges, as creatures of habit, used English legal materials to fill the gap. But citations to English decisions gradually disappeared during the <a2_0>19th century<a2_0/> as American courts developed their own principles to resolve the legal problems of the American people. The number of published volumes of American reports soared from <a3_0><a6_0><b14_0>eighteen<b14_0/><a6_0/><a3_0/> in 1810 to <a4_0><b12_0>over <a7_0>8,000<b12_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/> by 1910. <a8_0>By 1879 one of the delegates to the <b13_0>California<b13_0/> constitutional convention was already complaining<a8_0/>: "Now, when we require them to state the reasons for a decision, we do not mean they shall write a hundred pages of detail. We [do] not mean that they shall include the small cases, and impose on the country all this fine <a9_0>judicial literature<a9_0/>, for the Lord knows we have got enough of that already."
